name: Blue Agama
description: Its flat body with widely splayed legs is typical, an adaptation for moving across scorching surfaces. It has a blue head, a bluish upper tail, a yellow throat with blue spots, and a white-and-black pattern. During mating season, the coloration of both sexes becomes even more vivid.
spread_note: Rocky arid regions of North and Central America
food_note: Plant parts, fruits, small animals, buds, and other plant components
image_alt: Blue agama, photo: Petr Velenský, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 9–16 cm; tail length 12–18 cm
reproduction: Females lay 4–18 eggs; incubation lasts about 60 days.
attractions: It climbs rocks with great agility, even vertical walls, and can move upside down without difficulty. It intimidates rivals by bobbing its head, inflating the skin on its throat, and making strange guttural sounds.
breeding: We have kept blue agamas since 2008 and have successfully bred them.
